user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_Stub_GetReturnValuePtr:
```c
void *UT_Stub_GetReturnValuePtr(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, size_t ReturnSize, const char *TypeName)
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr;
    void *               ReturnPtr;

    ReturnPtr = NULL;
    StubPtr   = UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETURN_BUFFER);

    if (StubPtr == NULL)
    {
        /* This shouldn't happen, it means the stub tried to use a
         * return buffer that does not exist.
         *
         * It is most likely caused by a mismatch/incompatibility between
         * stub and handler.  Aborting now is better than segfaulting later,
         * as the errored call should still be on the stack trace
         */
        UtAssert_Abort("Return buffer invalid");
    }
    else
    {
        ReturnPtr = StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr;

        /*
         * Sanity check on the size and type name.
         *
         * In a generated stub these should always match, but if any patches
         * were done or if a hand-written stub is used, mistakes could be made.
         */
        if (StubPtr->Data.Buff.Position != ReturnSize || strcmp(TypeName, StubPtr->Data.Buff.ContentTypeStr) != 0)
        {
            UtAssert_Failed("Return value mismatch, expected %s(%lu) got %s(%lu)", TypeName, (unsigned long)ReturnSize,
                            StubPtr->Data.Buff.ContentTypeStr, (unsigned long)StubPtr->Data.Buff.Position);
        }
    }

    return ReturnPtr;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UT_Stub_GetReturnValuePtr:
typedef cpuaddr UT_EntryKey_t
...
typedef struct
{
    UT_EntryType_t EntryType;
    uint32         ModeFlags;
    UT_EntryKey_t  FuncKey;
    UT_EntryData_t Data;
} UT_StubTableEntry_t
...
static UT_StubTableEntry_t *UT_GetStubEntry(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, UT_EntryType_t TestMode)
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr   = NULL;
    uint32               Idx       = FuncKey % (UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS - 1); /* hash the key to determine the start point */
    uint32               SearchLen = 0;
    uint32               SearchLimit;
    UT_EntryKey_t        SearchKey;

    /* If searching for an unused entry, look through the entire table.
     * Otherwise bound the search */
    if (TestMode == UT_ENTRYTYPE_UNUSED)
    {
        SearchLimit = UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS;
        SearchKey   = 0;
    }
    else
    {
        SearchLimit = UT_MaxStubSearchLen;
        SearchKey   = FuncKey;
    }

    while (1)
    {
        if (SearchLen >= SearchLimit)
        {
            StubPtr = NULL;
            break;
        }
        ++SearchLen;
        StubPtr = &UT_StubTable[Idx];
        if (StubPtr->EntryType == TestMode && StubPtr->FuncKey == SearchKey)
        {
            break;
        }
        ++Idx;
        if (Idx >= UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS)
        {
            Idx = 0;
        }
    }

    /*
     * Keep track of the longest search length since the last reset.
     * This serves as the upper bound for future searches.
     */
    if (SearchLen > UT_MaxStubSearchLen)
    {
        UT_MaxStubSearchLen = SearchLen;
    }

    return StubPtr;
}
...
void UtAssert_Abort(const char *Message)
{
    UT_BSP_DoText(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_ABORT, Message);
}
...
#define UtAssert_Failed(__VA_ARGS__) UtAssertEx(false,UtAssert_GetContext(),__FILE__,__LINE__,__VA_ARGS__)
...
UtAssert_CaseType_t UtAssert_GetContext(void)
{
    return DefaultContext;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I reviewed the provided functions and related code for any assignments or modifications to function parameters (e.g. assignments to FuncKey, ReturnSize, TypeName, or Message). None of the functions modify their parameter identifiers: 

- UT_Stub_GetReturnValuePtr: FuncKey, ReturnSize and the pointer parameter TypeName are only read (passed to UT_GetStubEntry, used in comparisons/strcmp, and forwarded to UtAssert_Failed). The function assigns to local variables (StubPtr, ReturnPtr) but does not reassign any parameter.
- UT_GetStubEntry: the parameter FuncKey is used to compute local variables (Idx and SearchKey) and for comparisons; it is not assigned to or modified.
- UtAssert_Abort and UtAssert_GetContext: their parameters/returns are passed through and not modified.
- The UtAssert_Failed macro expands to a call and does not reassign any macro parameter.

No pointer parameter is reassigned (the pointer values are only read or passed to other functions), and there are no statements like "FuncKey = ...", "ReturnSize = ...", or "TypeName = ..." in the provided code. Therefore there are no fragments that appear to violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 in the supplied code.
